Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: ship in a clear glass bottle

A ship in a clear glass bottle with a cork stopper. This miniature galleon is housed in a medicinal vial that is only 1-1/4" long and only 1/2" in diameter, with a neck opening of less than 1/4". The model is very much simplified, due to it's tiny size.
A ship in a clear glass bottle with a cork stopper.
A rigging wire used to keep the mast from moving forward, as well as to vary the amount of bend in the mast.
Thin strips of wood or plastic inserted into batten pockets used to stiffen the leech.
A reinforcing rope along the luff or the foot of the sail, it is slid into a slot along the edge of a spar.
A spar (a wooden pole) attached to the mast at a right angle, used to support the foot of a sail.
A spar that's attached to the bow of the boat, along the centerline of the boat. The forestay can be attached to it - thus allowing for a greater sail area.
The bridge of the galleon rises above the stern of the vessel. It is likely where the captain oversees his crew.
The aft corner of the triangular sail.
The ribs of this ship are lashed in place with bast fibre cords, that were soaked in pitch to preserve them.
The ribs of this ship are lashed in place with bast fibre cords.
The main deck of a galleon. It is the central portion of this seafaring vessel.
The main deck of a galleon.
The main deck of a galleon.
A piece of hardware or equipment (such as a block) used for leading the jib sheets from the deck to the cockpit. They are located astern of the beam, on each side of the ship.
An attachment on the forestay, comprising a groove into which the luff of the jib can be fed.
The high, square forecastle of a galleon rises behind the bow. It would offer quite a view.
The foresail is the sail located immediately in front of the main mast. It is attached to the forestay.
The cable supporting the mast, running from the bow to the top of the mast.
The spar in a gaff rig to which the top side of the sailed is attached.
The top edge of the side of the hull.
The line used to raise things on a boat, for example "the main halyard" is the line used to raise the mainsail. It is a part of running rigging.
The snap attached to the luff of the jib, used to attach the jib to the forestay.
The sail located in front of the main mast.

The hardwood hull of a galleon. It is carvel-built which is the process of fixing planks to a frame so that the planks butt up against each other, gaining support from the frame and forming a smooth hull.
The line used to pull the jib in or let it out.
The aft edge of the triangular sail - the one that's not attached to anything.
The fore edge of the sail.
The line used to pull the mainsail in or let it out.
The pole attached to the deck at the right angle, holding up the sails.
The device located on the aft part of the boom, used to secure the clew, so that the foot is kept tense.
Part of the indispensable equipment on the boat. It is a small device used for attaching lines to other things, like sails.

A light, streamlined three-masted galleon in a bottle. This ship is housed in a medicinal vial that is only 1-1/4" long and only 1/2" in diameter, with a neck opening of less than 1/4". The model is very much simplified, due to it's tiny size. A high, square forecastle rises behind the bow, the three masts carry both square and lateen sails, and the broadside gunwale stands empty. The galleon has rigs with the addition of topmasts and three decks. The galleon can hold its position into the wind and use its broadside banks of cannon (if it had any, which it doesn't) to shell enemy ships or harbors lying at a distance.
A light, streamlined three-masted galleon in a bottle.
A light, streamlined three-masted galleon in a bottle. A high, square forecastle rises behind the bow, the three masts carry both square and lateen sails, and the broadside gunwale stands empty.
The wires holding the mast at the sides.
The pine spars of a galleon. These include all masts and yards.
The wooden struts that are attached horizontally to the upper section of the mast, on both sides. They widen the angle of the shrouds, and thus provide a better support for the mast.
Wires supporting the mast - fore and aft.
The fore corner of the triangular sail.
The snap used to hold the tack of the jib at the bow, while the sail is raised.
The pin used to secure the tack of the triangular sail at the mast.

Short pieces of yarn attached to the shrouds and the sails. At the shrouds they indicate the direction of the wind (the apparent wind), and at the sails they help to check the air flow over the sail, so that proper trimming is easier.
Most of the parts in this ship are held together with trenails, wooden pins that were split and wedged to hold them in place.
Most of the parts in this ship are held together with trenails.
The very small sail, used in a very heavy weather instead of a mainsail.
The spar on which the sail is suspended.
